reviewText:
You know what? I actually don't mind that this is much more simple and significantly easier than Twisted Dreams, superior of a game as it might be. The music is lovely as always and the sprites for Giana are fabulously detailed and animate.

What I do mind, however, are levels loading out of order if not two-to-three times in a row, sometimes brick walling progression in the progress. Poor background tiling and biased hit detection don't exactly make the experience any better, either.

A shame; this could have been a solid port of the DS title, but a complete lack of polish from outsourced development cripples that potential entirely.

reviewText:
Why do I not recommend it, well to put it simply not only is it blatantly lied about being a HD remake based on the Nintendo DS port, it also controls poorly and as mentioned by many of the reviews it has hitbox errors, graphical errors and there is no support being supplied.

If you come across bugs or issues don't expect them to be patched because since I've had the game the only thing I've seen patched in any way was the score system & I may not have had it long but it's been long enough that the reported bugs should have been tended to already.

While there are enjoyable factors to the game once you get to a set point the amount of infuriation you're going to endure, not because you're bad but because the game doesn't function like it should, you'd be better off playing an actual rage game or a game you know you're not good at but just need practice on and getting infuriated at that.  At least it will be because of yourself and not because of a badly implemented and designed game port.

reviewText:
Good news! Those of you who thought Giana Sisters: Twisted Dreams/Rise of the Owlverlord had levels much longer than they needed, this game is for you.

Bad news! It's a very poor phone port that doesn't do resolution correctly, has a bunch of collision issues, and is actually sort of ugly.

It's competent but it's nowhere near as creative as the newer GS titles, this is straight up a throwback to the Commodore era Mario-clone, and includes 32 retro" levels alongside the main game. (I admit it has been a long time since I booted a C64 to know if they're the original game's stages or just facsimiles.) It's full of content
date: but the whole package is sloppy. In the end
recommended: despite my love of the series

reviewText:
A Simplified Giana Sisters: Great for Newcomers, Little Challenge for Veterans

I was extremely happy to this game added to Steam since I have never been able to get my hands on a DS copy (Someday my pretty). So much so that I sent a copy to my sister. We both played the original Giana Sisters on Commodore 64 back in the day. It was essentially our Mario.

That is probably one of the flaws I find with the game: It's very easy for seasoned players. I think it is mainly because the power-ups have been scaled back from the original and boss enemies have been removed, at least from the 'Retro' levels. I don't know how far I have to go to find a boss in the newer levels, but thus far, there are none and I haven't gotten a game over yet on these newer levels.

That is not to say I don't recommend it. Far from. This is a great little platformer for one's collection and the price on sale is not bad at all at the time of writing this. The graphics are crisp and bright, controls work well, although the camera can be jerky at times, and you can customize the controls to your liking.

Black Forest Studios also got one thing spot on: Music. Giana Sisters was very famous for its chiptune music and the remixes are a delight to the ears, even for someone that generally has music turned down when playing.

And, although simplified, I am very happy for the addition of the retro levels as it brings back a bit of nostalgia.

To those that have maybe played Giana Sisters: Twisted Dreams, this is not that game, nor a sequel but a port of the DS version that many of us older Giana Sisters fans not in Europe either wished they had or had to import.

If you want a simple, cute platformer with awesome music, check this out. For veteran players such as myself, it is your call. For you, it may be more of a Giana Sisters Lite.

reviewText:
A quick review of Giana Sisters 2D!

+ The art style looks cute and they did a good job creating high resolution versions of all the DS artwork.
+ The music's great.
+ All the levels carry over from DS version, and though I haven't played through this entire port, I can remember enjoying playing through the game on DS.
+ You start with 112 million points.
- While kinda cool and funny, I'm pretty sure you're not supposed to start with 112 million points.
- I fell through a block, I walked over a bottomless pit, and I jumped through the ceiling a couple of times. The collision detection might be slightly buggy.
- When playing retro mode, the game would show the level number as I started each level. And I apparently I played level 1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 1, 3, 4, 1, 2, 3, 8-10, and 1. In that order. That doesn't sound quite right.
- There's one level where I'd die instantly as the level loaded, and that repeated until I had one life left. That was a bit awkward.
- There's various graphical artifacts when playing at 2560x1440. I didn't try lower resolutions so maybe they're fine.
- When getting hit, the character will start fading in and out for a few seconds. Makes it a bit tricky to actually see your character and line up jumps.

So yeah, the game's a bit buggy. I think I'd recommend the DS version over this port. But I'm still gonna give this a thumbs up as the music's great, and this is a pretty cheap price for pretty awesome music.

I'm still slightly baffled about the amount of points you start with. This is definitely the only game where I was pretty high up on the leaderboards without even having played the game yet. Maybe I'm just that good.

reviewText:
Good enough remake of a great game but needs some updates, it's is not like the Twisted Dreams games and plays similar to Super Mario Bros, but game the is a gem.

Positive points:
* Lots of stages
* Awesome  Music
* Simple yet fun gameplay

Neutral points:
* Short levels (in comparison to Twisted Dreams games)
* Very easy platformer for the most part, World 8 does get a bit dificult.
* Intro/ending cutscenes are 4:3 (neutral to me, they arent that long)

Negative:
* changed artstyle to something quite bad (the artstyle in the DS version is a lot better)
* few charcters animations missing from the DS game
* bazooka bee behavior was changed, on DS was easier to dodge, in this version it's from very hard to impossible to dodge when they shoot very fast  (if you dont have a Punk Giana power up).
* annoying minor bugs
* bubblegum power up mechanics are changed from the DS version and now it's awfully slow

for the most part the game is great, playing stages with involved the bubblegum power up were very annoying, most negative details can be noticed if the DS was played.

reviewText:
Well worth the money, especially at a discount.

Pros:

reviewText:
THIS is the series that had its tagline in its beginnings as “The brothers are history”!? The Mario Brothers have NOTHING to fear from this series. Giana Sisters 2D is my first venture into this beloved cult classic and I'm prepared to take the slings and arrows from the people who view this as some kind of sacred cow. WELL I believe NOTHING is sacred and EVERYTHING is up for ridicule and critique.

I had no expectations coming in. It looked like a cute platformer, and I love me some platformers. Some of my all time favorites are Super Mario Bros 3, Sonic 3 & Knuckles, Donkey Country 2 and Banjo & Kazooie. With that said, I found this to at first be alright, but the further I got along, the more the issues started to present themselves. All of them technical. And because of those technical difficulties it gives the game a bad case of fake difficulty[tvtropes.org]. These things being...

- Wonky placement of ceilings when jumps are concerned (these don't allow for wiggle room. Either get it right or die).

- Diamonds a plenty to try to hide these issues. You could get past all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t level design from world 3 forward if you just grind enough lives in earlier levels to give you a buffer and just keep tossing yourself at the levels until you win. Which makes you wonder why they couldn't just fix the erratic placement of BS blocks above you in tight spaces where there it a bottomless pit.

- Movement is wonky in segments. For example, if you try to move while the game is just starting, you remain in place until you let up.

- Hitboxes are wonky too on certain enemies. You will have PLENTY of times where you should be safe from an enemy and get hit anyway.

Overall, the tech issues (ESPECIALLY the ceiling issues) spoil what should be an otherwise middle-of-the-road, but still enjoyable platformer for me. If the above doesn't bother you, then get it while on sale. Don't recommend for full price unless you're one of the Giana faithful. As for me, unless a patch comes in to fix these issues, I'm done playing this game.

reviewText: I don't want to be too hard on this game, as it feels" like it was the very first game someone made in GameMaker
date:
but here goes nothing.

The Good:
+ Music is passable
+ Sound design is okay

The Bad:
- Collision is horrible
- Level themes are bland and overused
- Level design is either boring and uninspired or cruel
- Bubble controls are terrible (way too much inertia and way too slow)
- Enemies are boring and stupid looking (sorry)
- Backgrounds don't tile properly
- Boss battles are literally THE SAME boss every time (maybe just a teeny bit more difficult each time)
- GLITCHES IN LEVEL SELECT (sometimes the game can't decide which level I'm actually supposed to be playing)
- LEVELS REPEAT (there are at least four instances where the next level is IDENTICAL to the previous level)
- Levels are too short and too numerous (I think longer more memorable levels would've been better)
- Help tips are redundant
- Over-world is designed haphazardly and is a pain to navigate
- Main character sounds like a seagull when she dies
- YOU CAN MOVE DURING THE TITLE CARD FOR EACH LEVEL (you'll die a lot because of this)
- Secret levels not very rewarding to play (unless you are a completionist)

The Ugly:
* The Art (main character is okay though)"

reviewText:
As a fan of the Giana Sisters series, I think this is a good game. But it has a few issues:

-Non-perfect controller support (moving Giana with a D-Pad make Giana sometimes stop moving if you jump again after landing, but it doesnt happen with an analog stick though)
-Title screen may ocassionally glitch a lot, and it forces the user to exit full screen and coming back to full screen since it fixes the problem.
-If you quit too quickly a level the level's music continue playing in the menus


Even though its a buggy game, the game is still very good. There are no game breaking glitches, and (if you use keyboard and a controler with the analog stick) the controls are good, the level design is good and fun, the graphics are well made, and the soundtrack is enjoyable. If you like the Mario series, this is a must have! In fact, its a clone of Super Mario games.


Also, this is an easy game for beginners. Not only the difficulty is extremely fair for beginners, but so are the achievements for the game.

reviewText:
You know what? I actually don't mind that this is much more simple and significantly easier than Twisted Dreams, superior of a game as it might be. The music is lovely as always and the sprites for Giana are fabulously detailed and animate.

What I do mind, however, are levels loading out of order if not two-to-three times in a row, sometimes brick walling progression in the progress. Poor background tiling and biased hit detection don't exactly make the experience any better, either.

A shame; this could have been a solid port of the DS title, but a complete lack of polish from outsourced development cripples that potential entirely.

reviewText:
Why do I not recommend it, well to put it simply not only is it blatantly lied about being a HD remake based on the Nintendo DS port, it also controls poorly and as mentioned by many of the reviews it has hitbox errors, graphical errors and there is no support being supplied.

If you come across bugs or issues don't expect them to be patched because since I've had the game the only thing I've seen patched in any way was the score system & I may not have had it long but it's been long enough that the reported bugs should have been tended to already.

While there are enjoyable factors to the game once you get to a set point the amount of infuriation you're going to endure, not because you're bad but because the game doesn't function like it should, you'd be better off playing an actual rage game or a game you know you're not good at but just need practice on and getting infuriated at that.  At least it will be because of yourself and not because of a badly implemented and designed game port.

Even though its a buggy game, the game is still very good. There are no game breaking glitches, and (if you use keyboard and a controler with the analog stick) the controls are good, the level design is good and fun, the graphics are well made, and the soundtrack is enjoyable. If you like the Mario series, this is a must have! In fact, its a clone of Super Mario games.


Also, this is an easy game for beginners. Not only the difficulty is extremely fair for beginners, but so are the achievements for the game.

reviewText:
As a fan of the Giana Sisters series, I think this is a good game. But it has a few issues:

-Non-perfect controller support (moving Giana with a D-Pad make Giana sometimes stop moving if you jump again after landing, but it doesnt happen with an analog stick though)
-Title screen may ocassionally glitch a lot, and it forces the user to exit full screen and coming back to full screen since it fixes the problem.
-If you quit too quickly a level the level's music continue playing in the menus


Even though its a buggy game, the game is still very good. There are no game breaking glitches, and (if you use keyboard and a controler with the analog stick) the controls are good, the level design is good and fun, the graphics are well made, and the soundtrack is enjoyable. If you like the Mario series, this is a must have! In fact, its a clone of Super Mario games.


Also, this is an easy game for beginners. Not only the difficulty is extremely fair for beginners, but so are the achievements for the game.
